newsitem.title: USA: Existing homes sales drop in October.
newsitem.headline: Existing homes sales drop in October.

text.p: Sales of existing homes fell in October for the fifth straight month due to a slowing economy, and further declines were expected, a trade group said Monday.
Existing home sales fell 1.5 percent in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.97 million units from a revised 4.03 million units in September, the National Association of Realtors said.
"You will see housing numbers continue to come down," said John Tuccillo, chief economist at the association.
In coming months, home sales could slip to an annual rate of about 3.85 million to 3.9 million units, he said.
"We may edge up next month, but I seriously doubt it," Tuccillo said of the November data, which will be released in December.

The October sales rate showed a bigger decline than Wall Street economists' forecast of a drop to a 4.0 million unit annual rate. The October rate was down 2.5 percent from a 4.07 million unit sales rate in October 1995.

Existing home sales have declined steadily since setting a record in May of 4.28 million units at an annualized rate. The trade group is projecting 4.09 million sales of existing homes during 1996 and 3.84 million in 1997.
Tuccillo said the declines were due to the economy's slowing to about 2 percent growth.
Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgage rates were expected to fall by about a quarter of a percentage point through the end of the year and possibly by another quarter point early next year, Tuccillo said.
If that were to occur, it would probably set off a "rash" of refinancings, he said.
According to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., the national average commitment rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages in October was 7.92 percent, down from 8.23 percent in September.

The median sales price, the midpoint where half the homes sold for more and half for less, was $116,400 in October, down from $117,800 the prior month. The median price was higher than October 1995, when it was at $113,200.

Paul Taylor, senior economist at America's Community Bankers, said the build-up in the amount of existing homes waiting to be sold could have a spillover effect and slow sales of new homes if it continues to increase.
The Realtors' data showed that the number of existing homes available for sale rose to 2.36 million in October from 2.15 million in September and 1.89 million a year ago.
The October inventory would take 7.1 months to sell at the current pace, up from 6.4 months in September and 5.6 months in October 1995, according to the report.

"That's a significant number of additional houses that are out there for sale, but not selling," Taylor said. "This gradual accumulation has gotten to the point that it bears some focus as a sign that the economy is slowing somewhat."
